peer-address.description: The peer address or Tag of a neighbor. This attribute adds a neighbor. The specified neighbor when activated using the activate attribute exchanges routing information.

peer-as.description: This attribute specifies a neighbors autonomous system number. If the specified ASN matches the ASN number specified in the router bgp global configuration, the neighbor is identified as internal. If the ASN does not match, it is identified as external to the local AS.

source-identifier.description: This attribute allows internal BGP sessions to use any operational interface for TCP connections. Use this attribute in conjunction with any specified interface on the router. The loopback interface is the interface that is most commonly used with this attribute. The use of loopback interface eliminates a dependency and BGP does not have to rely on the availability of a particular interface for making TCP connections.

bgp-version.description: BGP Version. This attribute configures router to accept only a particular BGP version. By default, the system uses BGP version 4 and on request dynamically negotiates down to version 2. Using this attribute disables the routers version-negotiation capability and forces the router to use only a specified version with the neighbor.

peer-connection-interval.description: Connect timer value. This attribute sets the timers for a specific BGP neighbor. Keepalive messages are sent by a router to inform another router that the BGP connection between the two is still active. The keepalive interval is the period of time between each keepalive message sent by the router. The holdtime interval is the time the router waits to receive a keepalive message and if it does not receive a message for this period it declares the neighbor dead.

enforce-multihop.description: This attribute turns on the enforcement of eBGP neighbors perform multihop.

peer-shutdown.description: This attribute disables a neighbor administratively. Use this attribute to terminate any active session for a specified neighbor and clear all related routing information. In case a peer group is specified for shutdown, a large number of peering sessions could be terminated.

peer-shutdown-description.description: Use this attribute to send shutdown communication message to inform peer the reason for the shutdown of the BGP session.

neighbor-passive.description: Use this attribute to set a BGP neighbor as passive.

disable-capability-negotiation.description: Use this attribute to disable capability negotiation. The capability negotiation is performed by default. This attribute is used to allow compatibility with older BGP versions that have no capability parameters used in open messages between peers.

enable-dynamic-capability.description: Use this attribute to enable the dynamic capability for a specific peer. This attribute allows a BGP speaker to advertise or withdraw an address family capability to a peer in a non-disruptive manner.

min-route-advertisement-interval.description: Minimum route advertisement interval. Sets minimum interval between the sending of BGP routing updates. To reduce the flapping of routes to internet, a minimum advertisement interval is set, so that the BGP routing updates are sent only per interval seconds. BGP dampening can also be used to control the effects of flapping routes.

peer-as-origin-interval.description: Time interval. This attribute adjust the interval of sending AS origination routing updates. This attribute is used to change the minimum interval between the sending of AS-origination routing updates.

neighbor-as-override.description: Use this attribute to configure a PE router to override the Autonomous System Number (ASN) of a site with the ASN of a provider. BGP normally ignores the routes from the same AS. However, this attribute is used to override the customers ASN in BGP, so that the customer CE accepts and installs routes from the same AS. Typically, this attribute is used when Customer Edge (CE) routers have the same ASN in some or all sites. As per BGP requirement, a BGP speaker rejects a route that has the same ASN as itself, in the AS_PATH attribute. Thus the CE routers having the same ASN do not accept routes from each other. Set neighborAsOverrideAf attribute on the PE router removes the CE neighbors ASN from the AS_PATH attribute allowing CE routers with the same ASN to accept routes from each other.

peer-interface-name.description: Interface name. Configures IP address or IPv6 address on interface

peer-description.description: Use this attribute to associate a description with a neighbor. This attribute helps in identifying a neighbor quickly. It is useful for an ISP that has multiple neighbor relationships.

peer-restart-time.description: This attribute sets a different restart-time other than the global restart-time. This attribute takes precedence over the restart-time value specified using the graceful-restart-set attribute. The restart-time value is the maximum time that a graceful-restart neighbor waits to come back up after a restart. The default value is 120 seconds.

site-origin-identifier.description: Use this attribute to enable the site-of-origin (SOO) feature. If the customer AS is multi-homed to the ISP, this attribute ensures that the PE does not advertise the routes back to the same AS.

graceful-shut.description: Use this attribute to start a graceful shutdown for the BGP session of the specified BGP neighbor. The BGP session for this neighbor is shut down after the graceful shutdown timer expires. If there is no alternate path available for traffic to flow prior the actual shutdown of the BGP session, this path is made available for 60 seconds or for configured time after which the path is no longer available and traffic is dropped.

graceful-shut-timer.description: Use this attribute to configure the value of the graceful shutdown timer. After the timer expires, the BGP session initiated for graceful shutdown is shut down.

enable-peer-bfd.description: Enable bidirectional forwarding detection (BFD) for the BGP peer

enable-peer-bfd-multihop.description: Enable bidirectional forwarding detection (BFD) for the BGP peer with multihop

bgp-port.description: The BGP port number of a neighbor

activate.description: Activate/Deactivate neighbor. This attribute enables or disables the exchange of AF information with a neighboring router.

de-activate.description: Deactivate neighbor. This attribute disables the exchange of AF information with a neighboring router.

default-peer-route-map-name.description: This attribute allows a BGP local router to send the default route 0.0.0.0 to a neighbor for use as a default route for specified address-family.

peer-route-map-orig-name.description: This attribute configures route map to be used for a BGP local router to send the default route 0.0.0.0 to a neighbor for use as a default route for specified address-family. This attribute can be used with standard or extended access lists.

weight.description: This attribute specifies a weight value, for specified address-family, to all routes learned from a neighbor for specified address-family. The route with the highest weight gets preference when the same prefix is learned from more than one peer. Unlike the local-preference attribute, the weight attribute is relevant only to the local router. When the weight is set for a peer group, all members of the peer group get the same weight. This attribute can also be used to assign a different weight to an individual peer-group member. When an individually-configured weight of a peer-group member is removed, its weight is reset to its peer groups weight.

flowspec-validation-disable.description: This attribute specifies if FLOWSPEC validation should be disabled for a specific peer. By default, the flowspec validation is enabled, unless this option is specified.

peer-route-reflector.description: This attribute configures the router as a BGP route reflector and configure the specified neighbor as its client for specified address-family. Route reflectors are a solution for the explosion of iBGP peering within an autonomous system. By route reflection the number of iBGP peers within an AS is reduced. Use this attribute to configure the local router as the route reflector and specify neighbors as its client. An AS can have more than one route reflector. One route reflector treats the other route reflector as another iBGP speaker.

peer-remove-private-as.description: This attribute removes the private Autonomous System (AS) number from outbound updates. Private AS numbers are not advertised to the Internet. This attribute is used with external BGP peers only. The router removes the AS numbers only if the update includes private AS numbers. If the update includes both private and public AS numbers, the system treats it as an error.

no-send-community.description: This attribute specifies if a community attribute should be sent to a BGP neighbor for specified address-family. The community attribute groups destinations in a certain community and applies routing decisions according to those communities. By default, both standard and extended community attributes are sent to a neighbor

no-send-community-type.description: This attribute specifies the type of community attribute to be sent to a BGP neighbor.

neighbor-attribute-unchanged.description: This attribute advertises unchanged BGP AS path, next hop and med to the specified neighbor.

orf-prefix-capability.description: This attribute enables Outbound Router Filtering (ORF), and advertise the ORF capability to its neighbors. The ORFs send and receive capabilities to lessen the number of updates exchanged between neighbors. By filtering updates, this option minimizes generating and processing of updates. The two routers exchange updates to maintain the ORF for each router.

peer-allow-ebgp-vpn.description: This attribute allows an eBGP neighbor to be a VPN peer. By default, BGP VPN functionality is allowed only for iBGP peers. Using the peer-allow-ebgp-vpn attribute allows the VPN connection to be established to an eBGP peer.

allow-as-number.description: This attribute advertises prefixes (routes) even when the source of the prefixes is from the same Autonomous System (AS) number for specified address-family. Use this attribute in a scenario where two routers at different locations use the same Autonomous System number and are connected via an ISP. Once prefixes arrive from one branch at the ISP, they are tagged with the customers AS number. By default, when the ISP passes the prefixes to the other router, the prefixes are dropped if the other router uses the same AS number. Use this attribute to advertise the prefixes at the other side. Control the number of times an AS number is advertised by specifying a number. In a hub and spoke configuration in a VPN, a PE (Provider Edge) router advertises all prefixes containing duplicate AS numbers. Use this attribute to configure two VRFs on each PE router to receive and advertise prefixes. One of the VRFs receives prefixes with AS numbers from all PE routers and then advertises them to neighboring PE routers. The other VRF receives prefixes with AS numbers from the CE (Customer Edge) router and advertises them to all PE routers in the hub and spoke configuration.

capability-graceful-restart.description: This attribute configures the router to advertise the Graceful Restart Capability to the neighbors. This configuration indicates that the BGP speaker has the ability to preserve its forwarding state for the address family when BGP restarts. Use this attribute to advertise to the neighbor routers the capability of graceful restart.

mapped-peer-group-tag-af.description: BGP peer group name. Adds a neighbor to an existing peer group. Neighbors with the same update policies are grouped into peer groups. This facilitates the updates of various policies, such as distribute and filter lists. The peer group is then configured easily with any of the neighbor attributes. Any changes made to the peer group affect all members.

unsuppress-route-map-name.description: unsuppress map name. This attribute is used to selectively leak more-specific routes to a particular neighbor.

enable-ext-opt-param-len.description: Use this attribute for a specific peer to encode extended optional parameter length.

additional-paths-mode.description: Adds additional paths in the BGP table

additional-path-select-all.description: Attribute to select advertise additional path

additional-paths-best-select-count.description: Attribute to select best advertise additional path

tcp-adjust-mss.description: Use this attribute to set the BGP TCP MSS value of a neighbor.

state.description: State parameters relating to the VRF address family

counters.description: Container for the peer runtime counters

packet-in-queue.description: messages queued to be processed from the neighbor

packet-out-queue.description: messages queued to be sent to the neighbor

peer-address.description: The peer address or Tag of a neighbor. This attribute adds a neighbor. The specified neighbor when activated using the activate attribute exchanges routing information.

peer-as.description: This attribute specifies a neighbors autonomous system number. If the specified ASN matches the ASN number specified in the router bgp global configuration, the neighbor is identified as internal. If the ASN does not match, it is identified as external to the local AS.

source-identifier.description: This attribute allows internal BGP sessions to use any operational interface for TCP connections. Use this attribute in conjunction with any specified interface on the router. The loopback interface is the interface that is most commonly used with this attribute. The use of loopback interface eliminates a dependency and BGP does not have to rely on the availability of a particular interface for making TCP connections.

bgp-version.description: BGP Version. This attribute configures router to accept only a particular BGP version. By default, the system uses BGP version 4 and on request dynamically negotiates down to version 2. Using this attribute disables the routers version-negotiation capability and forces the router to use only a specified version with the neighbor.

peer-connection-interval.description: Connect timer value. This attribute sets the timers for a specific BGP neighbor. Keepalive messages are sent by a router to inform another router that the BGP connection between the two is still active. The keepalive interval is the period of time between each keepalive message sent by the router. The holdtime interval is the time the router waits to receive a keepalive message and if it does not receive a message for this period it declares the neighbor dead.

enforce-multihop.description: This attribute turns on the enforcement of eBGP neighbors perform multihop.

peer-shutdown.description: This attribute disables a neighbor administratively. Use this attribute to terminate any active session for a specified neighbor and clear all related routing information. In case a peer group is specified for shutdown, a large number of peering sessions could be terminated.

peer-shutdown-description.description: Use this attribute to send shutdown communication message to inform peer the reason for the shutdown of the BGP session.

neighbor-passive.description: Use this attribute to set a BGP neighbor as passive.

disable-capability-negotiation.description: Use this attribute to disable capability negotiation. The capability negotiation is performed by default. This attribute is used to allow compatibility with older BGP versions that have no capability parameters used in open messages between peers.

enable-dynamic-capability.description: Use this attribute to enable the dynamic capability for a specific peer. This attribute allows a BGP speaker to advertise or withdraw an address family capability to a peer in a non-disruptive manner.

min-route-advertisement-interval.description: Minimum route advertisement interval. Sets minimum interval between the sending of BGP routing updates. To reduce the flapping of routes to internet, a minimum advertisement interval is set, so that the BGP routing updates are sent only per interval seconds. BGP dampening can also be used to control the effects of flapping routes.

peer-as-origin-interval.description: Time interval. This attribute adjust the interval of sending AS origination routing updates. This attribute is used to change the minimum interval between the sending of AS-origination routing updates.

neighbor-as-override.description: Use this attribute to configure a PE router to override the Autonomous System Number (ASN) of a site with the ASN of a provider. BGP normally ignores the routes from the same AS. However, this attribute is used to override the customers ASN in BGP, so that the customer CE accepts and installs routes from the same AS. Typically, this attribute is used when Customer Edge (CE) routers have the same ASN in some or all sites. As per BGP requirement, a BGP speaker rejects a route that has the same ASN as itself, in the AS_PATH attribute. Thus the CE routers having the same ASN do not accept routes from each other. Set neighborAsOverrideAf attribute on the PE router removes the CE neighbors ASN from the AS_PATH attribute allowing CE routers with the same ASN to accept routes from each other.

password.description: Enable authentication-key on this interface to be used in message digest5 (MD5) authentication on a TCP connection between two BGP peers. Configuring MD5 authentication between two BGP peers, means that each segment sent on the TCP connection between the peers is verified. MD5 authentication must be configured with the same password on both BGP peers; otherwise, the connection between them will not be established.

auth-key-encrypt.description: Use this attribute to configure the authentication key to specify if the password is to be encrypted or not.

prefix-list-filters.description: Top level container for Prefix list Filter

config.description: Configuration parameters relating to BGP Prefix list Filter

prefix-list-name.description: This attribute specify a prefix list for filtering BGP advertisements for specified address-family. Filtering by prefix list matches the prefixes of routes with those listed in the prefix list. If there is a match, the route is used. An empty prefix list permits all prefixes. If a given prefix does not match any entries of a prefix list, the route is denied access. When multiple entries of a prefix list match a prefix, the entry with the smallest sequence number is considered to be a real match.The router begins the search at the top of the prefix list, with the sequence number 1. Once a match or deny occurs, the router does not need to go through the rest of the prefix list. For efficiency the most common matches or denies are listed at the top.

network-rmap-name.description: Use this attribute to configure route map for the network specified in local-network-prefix

backdoor.description: network address with backdoor for address family

state.description: state parameters for address-family network list

local-network-prefix.description: Use this attribute to specify the networks to be advertised by the BGP routing process. A unicast network address without a mask is accepted if it falls into the natural boundary of its class. A class-boundary mask is derived if the address matches its natural class-boundary.

network-rmap-name.description: Use this attribute to configure route map for the network specified in local-network-prefix

backdoor.description: network address with backdoor for address family

peer-group-tag.description: Creates a peer group. Neighbors with the same update policies are grouped into peer groups. This facilitates the updates of various policies, such as distribute and filter lists. The peer group is then configured easily with any of the neighbor attributes. Any changes made to the peer group affect all members.

config.description: Configuration parameters relating to the VRF address family

bgp-port.description: The BGP port number of a neighbor

activate.description: Activate/Deactivate neighbor. This attribute enables or disables the exchange of AF information with a neighboring router.

default-peer-route-map-name.description: This attribute allows a BGP local router to send the default route 0.0.0.0 to a neighbor for use as a default route for specified address-family.

peer-route-map-orig-name.description: This attribute configures route map to be used for a BGP local router to send the default route 0.0.0.0 to a neighbor for use as a default route for specified address-family. This attribute can be used with standard or extended access lists.

weight.description: This attribute specifies a weight value, for specified address-family, to all routes learned from a neighbor for specified address-family. The route with the highest weight gets preference when the same prefix is learned from more than one peer. Unlike the local-preference attribute, the weight attribute is relevant only to the local router. When the weight is set for a peer group, all members of the peer group get the same weight. This attribute can also be used to assign a different weight to an individual peer-group member. When an individually-configured weight of a peer-group member is removed, its weight is reset to its peer groups weight.

flowspec-validation-disable.description: This attribute specifies if FLOWSPEC validiation should be disabled for a specific peer

peer-route-reflector.description: This attribute configures the router as a BGP route reflector and configure the specified neighbor as its client for specified address-family. Route reflectors are a solution for the explosion of iBGP peering within an autonomous system. By route reflection the number of iBGP peers within an AS is reduced. Use this attribute to configure the local router as the route reflector and specify neighbors as its client. An AS can have more than one route reflector. One route reflector treats the other route reflector as another iBGP speaker.

peer-remove-private-as.description: This attribute removes the private Autonomous System (AS) number from outbound updates. Private AS numbers are not advertised to the Internet. This attribute is used with external BGP peers only. The router removes the AS numbers only if the update includes private AS numbers. If the update includes both private and public AS numbers, the system treats it as an error.

no-send-community.description: This attribute specifies if a community attribute should be sent to a BGP neighbor for specified address-family. The community attribute groups destinations in a certain community and applies routing decisions according to those communities. By default, both standard and extended community attributes are sent to a neighbor

no-send-community-type.description: This attribute specifies the type of community attribute to be sent to a BGP neighbor.

neighbor-attribute-unchanged.description: This attribute advertises unchanged BGP AS path, next hop and med to the specified neighbor.

orf-prefix-capability.description: This attribute enables Outbound Router Filtering (ORF), and advertise the ORF capability to its neighbors. The ORFs send and receive capabilities to lessen the number of updates exchanged between neighbors. By filtering updates, this option minimizes generating and processing of updates. The two routers exchange updates to maintain the ORF for each router.

peer-allow-ebgp-vpn.description: This attribute allows an eBGP neighbor to be a VPN peer. By default, BGP VPN functionality is allowed only for iBGP peers. Using the peer-allow-ebgp-vpn attribute allows the VPN connection to be established to an eBGP peer.

allow-as-number.description: This attribute advertises prefixes (routes) even when the source of the prefixes is from the same Autonomous System (AS) number for specified address-family. Use this attribute in a scenario where two routers at different locations use the same Autonomous System number and are connected via an ISP. Once prefixes arrive from one branch at the ISP, they are tagged with the customers AS number. By default, when the ISP passes the prefixes to the other router, the prefixes are dropped if the other router uses the same AS number. Use this attribute to advertise the prefixes at the other side. Control the number of times an AS number is advertised by specifying a number. In a hub and spoke configuration in a VPN, a PE (Provider Edge) router advertises all prefixes containing duplicate AS numbers. Use this attribute to configure two VRFs on each PE router to receive and advertise prefixes. One of the VRFs receives prefixes with AS numbers from all PE routers and then advertises them to neighboring PE routers. The other VRF receives prefixes with AS numbers from the CE (Customer Edge) router and advertises them to all PE routers in the hub and spoke configuration.

capability-graceful-restart.description: This attribute configures the router to advertise the Graceful Restart Capability to the neighbors. This configuration indicates that the BGP speaker has the ability to preserve its forwarding state for the address family when BGP restarts. Use this attribute to advertise to the neighbor routers the capability of graceful restart.

unsuppress-route-map-name.description: unsuppress map name. This attribute is used to selectively leak more-specific routes to a particular neighbor.

additional-paths-mode.description: Adds additional paths in the BGP table

additional-path-select-all.description: Attribute to select advertise additional path

additional-paths-best-select-count.description: Attribute to select best advertise additional path

peer-group-range.description: this attribute creates a Dynamic peer group for address family. IPv4/IPv6 prefix range Must be specified to create dynamic peer group.

group-limit.description: Use this attribute to specify max number of peers in a dynamic peer-group for address family

peer-group-tag.description: The peer address or Tag of a neighbor. This attribute adds a neighbor. The specified neighbor when activated using the activate attribute exchanges routing information.

peer-as.description: This attribute specifies a neighbors autonomous system number. If the specified ASN matches the ASN number specified in the router bgp global configuration, the neighbor is identified as internal. If the ASN does not match, it is identified as external to the local AS.

source-identifier.description: This attribute allows internal BGP sessions to use any operational interface for TCP connections. Use this attribute in conjunction with any specified interface on the router. The loopback interface is the interface that is most commonly used with this attribute. The use of loopback interface eliminates a dependency and BGP does not have to rely on the availability of a particular interface for making TCP connections.

bgp-version.description: BGP Version. This attribute configures router to accept only a particular BGP version. By default, the system uses BGP version 4 and on request dynamically negotiates down to version 2. Using this attribute disables the routers version-negotiation capability and forces the router to use only a specified version with the neighbor.

peer-connection-interval.description: Connect timer value. This attribute sets the timers for a specific BGP neighbor. Keepalive messages are sent by a router to inform another router that the BGP connection between the two is still active. The keepalive interval is the period of time between each keepalive message sent by the router. The holdtime interval is the time the router waits to receive a keepalive message and if it does not receive a message for this period it declares the neighbor dead.

enforce-multihop.description: This attribute turns on the enforcement of eBGP neighbors perform multihop.

peer-shutdown.description: This attribute disables a neighbor administratively. Use this attribute to terminate any active session for a specified neighbor and clear all related routing information. In case a peer group is specified for shutdown, a large number of peering sessions could be terminated.

peer-shutdown-description.description: Use this attribute to send shutdown communication message to inform peer the reason for the shutdown of the BGP session.

neighbor-passive.description: Use this attribute to set a BGP neighbor as passive.

disable-capability-negotiation.description: Use this attribute to disable capability negotiation. The capability negotiation is performed by default. This attribute is used to allow compatibility with older BGP versions that have no capability parameters used in open messages between peers.

connection-retry-interval.description: Connect timer value. Sets the connection retry time for a specific BGP neighbor.

enable-dynamic-capability.description: Use this attribute to enable the dynamic capability for a specific peer. This attribute allows a BGP speaker to advertise or withdraw an address family capability to a peer in a non-disruptive manner.

min-route-advertisement-interval.description: Minimum route advertisement interval. Sets minimum interval between the sending of BGP routing updates. To reduce the flapping of routes to internet, a minimum advertisement interval is set, so that the BGP routing updates are sent only per interval seconds. BGP dampening can also be used to control the effects of flapping routes.

peer-as-origin-interval.description: Time interval. This attribute adjust the interval of sending AS origination routing updates. This attribute is used to change the minimum interval between the sending of AS-origination routing updates.

neighbor-as-override.description: Use this attribute to configure a PE router to override the Autonomous System Number (ASN) of a site with the ASN of a provider. BGP normally ignores the routes from the same AS. However, this attribute is used to override the customers ASN in BGP, so that the customer CE accepts and installs routes from the same AS. Typically, this attribute is used when Customer Edge (CE) routers have the same ASN in some or all sites. As per BGP requirement, a BGP speaker rejects a route that has the same ASN as itself, in the AS_PATH attribute. Thus the CE routers having the same ASN do not accept routes from each other. Set neighborAsOverrideAf attribute on the PE router removes the CE neighbors ASN from the AS_PATH attribute allowing CE routers with the same ASN to accept routes from each other.

peer-description.description: Use this attribute to associate a description with a neighbor. This attribute helps in identifying a neighbor quickly. It is useful for an ISP that has multiple neighbor relationships.

peer-restart-time.description: This attribute sets a different restart-time other than the global restart-time. This attribute takes precedence over the restart-time value specified using the graceful-restart-set attribute. The restart-time value is the maximum time that a graceful-restart neighbor waits to come back up after a restart. The default value is 120 seconds.

site-origin-identifier.description: Use this attribute to enable the site-of-origin (SOO) feature. If the customer AS is multi-homed to the ISP, this attribute ensures that the PE does not advertise the routes back to the same AS.

graceful-shut.description: Use this attribute to start a graceful shutdown for the BGP session of the specified BGP neighbor. The BGP session for this neighbor is shut down after the graceful shutdown timer expires. If there is no alternate path available for traffic to flow prior the actual shutdown of the BGP session, this path is made available for 60 seconds or for configured time after which the path is no longer available and traffic is dropped.

graceful-shut-timer.description: Use this attribute to configure the value of the graceful shutdown timer. After the timer expires, the BGP session initiated for graceful shutdown is shut down.

enable-peer-bfd.description: Enable bidirectional forwarding detection (BFD) for the BGP peer

enable-peer-bfd-multihop.description: Enable bidirectional forwarding detection (BFD) for the BGP peer with multihop

enable-ext-opt-param-len.description: Use this attribute for a specific peer to encode extended optional parameter length.

tcp-adjust-mss.description: Use this attribute to set the BGP TCP MSS value of a neighbor.

state.description: State parameters relating to the VRF address family

bgp-port.description: The BGP port number of a neighbor

activate.description: Activate/Deactivate neighbor. This attribute enables or disables the exchange of AF information with a neighboring router.

default-peer-route-map-name.description: This attribute allows a BGP local router to send the default route 0.0.0.0 to a neighbor for use as a default route for specified address-family.

peer-route-map-orig-name.description: This attribute configures route map to be used for a BGP local router to send the default route 0.0.0.0 to a neighbor for use as a default route for specified address-family. This attribute can be used with standard or extended access lists.

optional-as-lists.description: Top level container for optional AS

optional-as.description: Use this attribute to specify optional AS for BGP dynamic peer-group

config.description: Configuration of optional AS list

optional-as.description: This attribute specifies an optional AS Number to a dynamic peer-group

state.description: State parameters of optional AS list

optional-as.description: This attribute specifies an optional AS Number to a dynamic peer-group

bgp-passwords.description: Top level container for BGP password

password.description: Use this attribute to specify BGP encrypted password

config.description: Configuration parameters relating to the BGP password

password.description: Enable authentication-key on this interface to be used in message digest5 (MD5) authentication on a TCP connection between two BGP peers. Configuring MD5 authentication between two BGP peers, means that each segment sent on the TCP connection between the peers is verified. MD5 authentication must be configured with the same password on both BGP peers; otherwise, the connection between them will not be established.

auth-key-encrypt.description: Use this attribute to configure the authentication key to specify if the password is to be encrypted or not.

state.description: State parameters relating to the BGP password

password.description: Enable authentication-key on this interface to be used in message digest5 (MD5) authentication on a TCP connection between two BGP peers. Configuring MD5 authentication between two BGP peers, means that each segment sent on the TCP connection between the peers is verified. MD5 authentication must be configured with the same password on both BGP peers; otherwise, the connection between them will not be established.

auth-key-encrypt.description: Use this attribute to configure the authentication key to specify if the password is to be encrypted or not.

keep-alive.description: Use this attribute to globally set or reset the keepalive values for all the neighbors

hold-time.description: Use this attribute to globally set or reset the holdtime values for all the neighbors.

hold-time.description: Use this attribute to globally set or reset the holdtime values for all the neighbors.

no-prepend-local-as.description: Use this attribute to stop the alternate ASN from being prepended when receiving routes from EBGP bgp neighbor.

replace-local-as.description: Use this attribute to stop the alternate ASN from being prepended when sending routes to EBGP bgp neighbor.

config.description: configuration parameters relating to EBGP multihop

maximum-hop-count.description: Use this attribute to configure the the maximum hop count for EBGP multihop.

enabled.description: Use this attribute to accept and attempt BGP connections to external peers on indirectly connected networks. Multihop is not established if the only route to the multihop peer is a default route. This avoids loop formation.

state.description: state parameters relating to timers

maximum-hop-count.description: Use this attribute to configure the the maximum hop count for EBGP multihop.

enabled.description: Use this attribute to accept and attempt BGP connections to external peers on indirectly connected networks. Multihop is not established if the only route to the multihop peer is a default route. This avoids loop formation.

maximum-prefixes.description: Top level container for Prefix related configuration

prefix-count.description: This attribute specifies number of prefixes that a BGP router is allowed to receive from a neighbor. When the maximum-prefix-warning attribute is not set and extra prefixes are received, the router ends the peering.

config.description: Configuration parameters relating to the number of prefixes that can    be received from a neighbor

prefix-count.description: This attribute specifies number of prefixes that a BGP router is allowed to receive from a neighbor. When the maximum-prefix-warning attribute is not set and extra prefixes are received, the router ends the peering.

stop-update.description: Stop installing the routes when limit is exceeded.

maximum-prefix-warning.description: This attribute when enabled only give warning message when limit is exceeded. When it is not set and extra prefixes are received, the router ends the peering.

threshold-percentage.description: Threshold-value in percen. This attribute controls the number of prefixes that can be received from a neighbor. This attribute allows the configuration of a specified number of prefixes that a BGP router is allowed to receive from a neighbor. When the maximum-prefix-warning attribute is not set and extra prefixes are received, the router ends the peering.

filter-direction.description: This attribute sets the direction of the filter (0=FILTER_IN |1=FILTER_OUT). This attribute is used to filter route updates from a particular BGP neighbor for specified address-family. Only one distribute-list per BGP neighbor.

config.description: Configuration parameters relating to BGP Distribute list Filter

filter-direction.description: This attribute sets the direction of the filter (0=FILTER_IN |1=FILTER_OUT). This attribute is used to filter route updates from a particular BGP neighbor for specified address-family. Only one distribute-list per BGP neighbor.

state.description: State parameters relating to BGP Distribute list Filter

filter-direction.description: This attribute sets the direction of the filter (0=FILTER_IN |1=FILTER_OUT). This attribute is used to filter route updates from a particular BGP neighbor for specified address-family. Only one distribute-list per BGP neighbor.

config.description: Configuration parameters relating to BGP AS list Filter

as-access-list-identifier.description: Access-list number. This attribute sets a BGP filter. This attribute specifies an access list filter on updates based on the BGP autonomous system paths. Each filter is an access list based on regular expressions

state.description: State parameters relating to BGP AS list Fileter

as-access-list-identifier.description: Access-list number. This attribute sets a BGP filter. This attribute specifies an access list filter on updates based on the BGP autonomous system paths. Each filter is an access list based on regular expressions

config.description: Configuration parameters relating to BGP Prefix list Filter

prefix-list-name.description: This attribute specify a prefix list for filtering BGP advertisements for specified address-family. Filtering by prefix list matches the prefixes of routes with those listed in the prefix list. If there is a match, the route is used. An empty prefix list permits all prefixes. If a given prefix does not match any entries of a prefix list, the route is denied access. When multiple entries of a prefix list match a prefix, the entry with the smallest sequence number is considered to be a real match.The router begins the search at the top of the prefix list, with the sequence number 1. Once a match or deny occurs, the router does not need to go through the rest of the prefix list. For efficiency the most common matches or denies are listed at the top.

state.description: State parameters relating to BGP Prefix list Filter

prefix-list-name.description: This attribute specify a prefix list for filtering BGP advertisements for specified address-family. Filtering by prefix list matches the prefixes of routes with those listed in the prefix list. If there is a match, the route is used. An empty prefix list permits all prefixes. If a given prefix does not match any entries of a prefix list, the route is denied access. Once a match or deny occurs, the router does not need to go through the rest of the prefix list. For efficiency the most common matches or denies are listed at the top.

route-map-direction.description: Use this attribute to configure the direction in which the route map.

config.description: Configuration parameters relating to BGP Route map Filter

route-map-name.description: Use this attribute to apply a route map to incoming or outgoing routes. This attribute filters updates and modifies attributes. A route map is applied to inbound or outbound updates. Only the routes that pass the route map are sent or accepted in updates.

route-map-direction.description: Use this attribute to configure the direction in which the route map is to be applied. Direction of the filter (0=FILTER_IN |1=FILTER_OUT).

state.description: State parameters relating to BGP Route map Filter

route-map-name.description: Use this attribute to apply a route map to incoming or outgoing routes. This attribute filters updates and modifies attributes. A route map is applied to inbound or outbound updates. Only the routes that pass the route map are sent or accepted in updates.

route-map-direction.description: Use this attribute to configure the direction in which the route map is to be applied. Direction of the filter (0=FILTER_IN |1=FILTER_OUT).
